states.name: Tamil Nadu

facts.famousFood: Idli, Dosa, Sambar, Pongal, Chettinad Cuisine

states.history: Tamil Nadu, earlier part of the Madras Presidency, became a separate state in 1950 and was renamed Tamil Nadu in 1969. It is the heartland of Dravidian culture, with an unbroken tradition of Tamil language, temple architecture, classical dance (Bharatanatyam), and literature for over 2,000 years. It was a stronghold of early dynasties like the Cholas, Pandyas, and Pallavas. Politically, it has been dominated by Dravidian parties since the 1960s.

touristPlaces.name: Meenakshi Amman Temple
touristPlaces.description: Magnificent Dravidian-style temple in Madurai dedicated to Goddess Meenakshi.

touristPlaces.name: Marina Beach
touristPlaces.description: One of the longest beaches in the world, located in Chennai.

touristPlaces.name: Mahabalipuram
touristPlaces.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its ancient temples and rock carvings by the sea.

touristPlaces.name: Ooty
touristPlaces.description: Popular hill station in the Nilgiri Hills known for its tea plantations and scenic beauty.
touristPlaces.bestTimeToVisit: April to June, September to November

touristPlaces.name: Kanyakumari
touristPlaces.description: Southernmost tip of India, famous for Vivekananda Rock Memorial and sunset views.

states.name: Kerala

facts.famousFood: Appam, Puttu, Fish Curry, Sadhya, Karimeen Pollichathu

states.history: Kerala was formed on November 1, 1956, by merging Travancore, Cochin, and Malabar regions. It has an ancient history of trade with Romans, Arabs, and Chinese. Known as the land of spices, it was colonized by the Portuguese, Dutch, and finally the British. The region also has a strong tradition of literacy, social reform, and religious harmony. Kerala is now celebrated for its backwaters, high human development index, and progressive governance.

touristPlaces.name: Alleppey Backwaters
touristPlaces.description: Famous for its network of canals, houseboats, and paddy fields.

touristPlaces.name: Munnar
touristPlaces.description: Hill station known for its sprawling tea plantations and cool climate.

touristPlaces.name: Kumarakom Bird Sanctuary
touristPlaces.description: Sanctuary on Vembanad Lake attracting migratory birds.

touristPlaces.name: Kovalam Beach
touristPlaces.description: Famous beach destination near Thiruvananthapuram.

touristPlaces.name: Periyar Wildlife Sanctuary
touristPlaces.description: Popular for elephants, tigers, and boating in Periyar Lake.

states.name: Karnataka

facts.famousFood: Bisi Bele Bath, Mysore Masala Dosa, Ragi Mudde, Neer Dosa

states.history: Karnataka, earlier known as the State of Mysore, was renamed in 1973. It was formed on November 1, 1956, after merging Kannada-speaking regions from Bombay, Hyderabad, Madras, and Coorg states. Historically, it was home to powerful dynasties like the Chalukyas, Hoysalas, and the Vijayanagara Empire, which had its capital in Hampi. Under the British, the princely state of Mysore was ruled by the Wodeyar dynasty. Today, Karnataka is known for its IT hub Bengaluru, rich cultural legacy, and classical music traditions.

touristPlaces.name: Coorg
touristPlaces.description: Known as Scotland of India, famous for coffee plantations and hills.

touristPlaces.name: Bandipur National Park
touristPlaces.description: A tiger reserve and part of the Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve.

touristPlaces.name: Gokarna
touristPlaces.description: Pilgrimage town with pristine beaches and the famous Om Beach.

touristPlaces.name: Hampi
touristPlaces.description: UNESCO World Heritage Site with ruins of the Vijayanagara Empire.

touristPlaces.name: Mysore Palace
touristPlaces.description: Historical palace and royal residence of the Wadiyar dynasty.
touristPlaces.significance: Most visited monument in India after Taj Mahal

states.name: Maharashtra

facts.famousFood: Vada Pav, Misal Pav, Puran Poli, Poha, Kolhapuri Chicken

states.history: Maharashtra was formed on May 1, 1960, along with Gujarat, from the bilingual Bombay State. Historically, the region was part of the Maurya Empire and later ruled by the Satavahanas, Yadavas, Mughals, and the Maratha Empire led by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. Under the British, Bombay became a major trading hub. Post-independence, Maharashtra has evolved into an economic powerhouse and is home to Mumbai, India’s financial capital and Bollywood center.

touristPlaces.name: Ajanta & Ellora Caves
touristPlaces.description: UNESCO World Heritage Sites with ancient rock-cut cave monuments.

touristPlaces.name: Gateway of India
touristPlaces.description: Iconic arch monument built during British rule in Mumbai.

touristPlaces.name: Shirdi
touristPlaces.description: Pilgrimage town famous as the home of Sai Baba.

touristPlaces.name: Mahabaleshwar
touristPlaces.description: A hill station in the Western Ghats known for strawberries and viewpoints.

states.name: Rajasthan

facts.famousFood: Dal Baati Churma, Ghewar, Laal Maas, Ker Sangri

states.history: Rajasthan, the Land of Kings, was formed by merging over 22 princely states after independence, with the process completed in 1956. Before that, it was known as Rajputana, ruled by powerful Rajput clans like the Sisodias, Rathores, and Chauhans. The region was known for its valor, forts (like Chittorgarh, Jaisalmer, and Mehrangarh), and resistance to Mughal rule. It became a unified state with Jaipur as its capital and remains a major center of tourism and heritage.

touristPlaces.name: Jaipur City Palace
touristPlaces.description: Royal residence with museums, courtyards and gardens in the Pink City.
touristPlaces.significance: Part of UNESCO World Heritage Site

touristPlaces.name: Udaipur Lake Palace
touristPlaces.description: Romantic luxury hotel on an island in Lake Pichola.
touristPlaces.significance: One of the most beautiful palaces in the world

touristPlaces.name: Jaisalmer Fort
touristPlaces.description: Also called 'Golden Fort', it is one of the largest living forts in the world.

touristPlaces.name: Hawa Mahal
touristPlaces.description: The 'Palace of Winds' with 953 windows, built in 1799.

touristPlaces.name: Mount Abu
touristPlaces.description: Rajasthan’s only hill station, famous for Dilwara Jain temples.

states.name: Uttar Pradesh
states.history: Uttar Pradesh (UP) was known as the United Provinces under British rule and was renamed UP in 1950. Historically, it was the seat of Hindu epics (like Ayodhya and Mathura), Buddhism (Sarnath and Kushinagar), and Mughal glory (Agra and Fatehpur Sikri). It played a central role in India’s freedom movement with leaders like Gandhi, Nehru, and Subhas Chandra Bose visiting or originating from the region. It is India’s most populous and politically dominant state.

touristPlaces.name: Taj Mahal
touristPlaces.description: One of the Seven Wonders of the World in Agra.

touristPlaces.name: Varanasi Ghats
touristPlaces.description: Spiritual heart of India with ancient temples and Ganga Aarti.
touristPlaces.significance: One of the oldest cities in the world

touristPlaces.name: Fatehpur Sikri
touristPlaces.description: A Mughal UNESCO heritage site built by Emperor Akbar.

touristPlaces.name: Ayodhya Ram Mandir
touristPlaces.description: Recently built grand temple dedicated to Lord Rama.

touristPlaces.name: Sarnath
touristPlaces.description: Buddhist pilgrimage site where Gautama Buddha gave his first sermon.

states.name: Bihar
states.history: Bihar, the cradle of ancient Indian civilization, was the home of the Mauryan and Gupta empires, and the birthplaces of Buddhism and Jainism. Nalanda and Vikramshila, once world-renowned universities, thrived here. Under the British, it was part of the Bengal Presidency but became a separate province in 1912. Post-independence, it remained a large state until Jharkhand was separated in 2000. While facing development challenges, it remains politically influential.

touristPlaces.name: Bodh Gaya
touristPlaces.description: Place where Gautama Buddha attained enlightenment.

touristPlaces.name: Nalanda University
touristPlaces.description: Ancient center of learning.

touristPlaces.name: Mahabodhi Temple
touristPlaces.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Buddhist temple in Bodh Gaya where Lord Buddha attained enlightenment.

touristPlaces.name: Rajgir
touristPlaces.description: Historic town associated with Lord Buddha and Lord Mahavira, with hot springs and ropeway.

touristPlaces.name: Vaishali
touristPlaces.description: Birthplace of Lord Mahavira and an important Buddhist and Jain pilgrimage site.

states.name: Madhya Pradesh

facts.famousFood: Poha, Bhutte ka Kees, Dal Bafla

states.history: Madhya Pradesh, often called the 'Heart of India', was formed on November 1, 1956, by merging Madhya Bharat, Vindhya Pradesh, Bhopal, and Central Provinces & Berar. It was home to great dynasties like the Mauryas, Guptas, Paramaras, and Mughals. Sites like Khajuraho, Sanchi, and Bhimbetka bear witness to its ancient cultural glory. In 2000, Chhattisgarh was carved out to improve governance in tribal areas.

touristPlaces.name: Bandhavgarh National Park
touristPlaces.description: Famous tiger reserve with the highest density of Bengal tigers.

touristPlaces.name: Bhopal Upper Lake
touristPlaces.description: Asia’s largest artificial lake, popular for boating and scenic beauty.

touristPlaces.name: Gwalior Fort
touristPlaces.description: A hill fort known as 'the pearl among Indian forts'.

touristPlaces.name: Khajuraho
touristPlaces.description: Famous for its stunning erotic rock carvings and temples.

touristPlaces.name: Sanchi Stupa
touristPlaces.description: Buddhist complex with one of the oldest stone structures in India.

states.name: Andhra Pradesh

facts.famousFood: Pulihora, Andhra Chicken Curry, Gongura Pickle

states.history: Andhra Pradesh holds the distinction of being the first state formed on a linguistic basis in India. After years of demands for a separate Telugu-speaking state, it was carved out of the Madras Presidency on October 1, 1953, with Kurnool as the capital. The demand intensified following the death of Potti Sriramulu, who died fasting for this cause. Later, in 1956, under the States Reorganisation Act, Andhra merged with the Telangana region (which was part of Hyderabad State) to form a united Andhra Pradesh. However, after prolonged agitation, Telangana was separated in 2014, making Andhra Pradesh a reorganized state. It now plans Visakhapatnam as its executive capital.

touristPlaces.name: Tirupati Temple
touristPlaces.description: One of the richest and most visited religious shrines in the world.

touristPlaces.name: Araku Valley
touristPlaces.description: A scenic hill station known for its coffee plantations and tribal culture.

touristPlaces.name: Amaravati
touristPlaces.description: Historical site with ancient Buddhist stupas and proposed state capital.

touristPlaces.name: Borra Caves
touristPlaces.description: Natural limestone caves with stalactites and stalagmites near Visakhapatnam.

touristPlaces.name: Kailasagiri
touristPlaces.description: A hilltop park in Visakhapatnam offering panoramic views and giant Shiva-Parvati statues.

states.name: Assam
states.history: Assam has a rich ancient history linked with the Kamarupa kingdom and later the Ahom dynasty, which ruled for over 600 years. It became a part of British India in 1826 through the Treaty of Yandabo after the First Anglo-Burmese War. Assam was originally a large province and was gradually reduced as Nagaland (1963), Meghalaya (1972), Mizoram (1987), and Arunachal Pradesh (1987) were carved out. Known for its tea estates, Kaziranga National Park, and ethnic diversity, Assam has also seen periods of unrest including the Assam Agitation (1979–1985).

touristPlaces.name: Kaziranga National Park
touristPlaces.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, home to the largest population of one-horned rhinoceroses.

touristPlaces.name: Majuli
touristPlaces.description: World's largest river island known for its monasteries and festivals.

touristPlaces.name: Kamakhya Temple
touristPlaces.description: A revered Shakti Peetha temple in Guwahati.

touristPlaces.name: Sivasagar
touristPlaces.description: Historic Ahom kingdom capital with temples and palaces.

touristPlaces.name: Manas National Park
touristPlaces.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site and tiger reserve on the Bhutan border.

states.name: Arunachal Pradesh
states.tagline: The Land of the Rising Sun
states.history: Known as the 'Land of the Rising Sun', Arunachal Pradesh was originally part of Assam and remained under the North-East Frontier Agency (NEFA) during British rule and early post-independence years. Due to its strategic importance, it was administered separately. It became a Union Territory in 1972 and was granted full statehood on February 20, 1987. The region has a distinct identity with over 26 tribes and 100+ sub-tribes, and has seen tensions with China, which claims parts of it.

touristPlaces.name: Tawang Monastery
touristPlaces.description: One of the largest Buddhist monasteries in India, located in the Tawang Valley.

touristPlaces.name: Ziro Valley
touristPlaces.description: A lush green valley known for the Ziro Music Festival and Apatani tribal heritage.

touristPlaces.name: Namdapha National Park
touristPlaces.description: A biodiversity hotspot and the largest protected area in the Eastern Himalaya.

touristPlaces.name: Bomdila
touristPlaces.description: A serene hill station with monasteries, apple orchards, and Himalayan views.

touristPlaces.name: Sela Pass
touristPlaces.description: A high-altitude mountain pass at 13,700 ft offering breathtaking views and a sacred lake.

states.name: Chhattisgarh
states.history: Chhattisgarh was part of Madhya Pradesh until it was carved out on November 1, 2000, due to demands for better administration for its tribal-dominated regions. Rich in natural resources, forests, and minerals, it also has ancient links to the Mauryan and Gupta empires. The state has faced Naxalite insurgency issues in some regions but continues to develop its tribal and agricultural economy.

touristPlaces.name: Chitrakote Falls
touristPlaces.description: The widest waterfall in India, often called the 'Niagara of India'.

touristPlaces.name: Barnawapara Sanctuary
touristPlaces.description: A peaceful wildlife sanctuary known for leopards and antelopes.

touristPlaces.name: Kanger Valley National Park
touristPlaces.description: Rich in biodiversity, waterfalls, and limestone caves.

touristPlaces.name: Sirpur
touristPlaces.description: Historic site with Buddhist and Hindu archaeological remains.

touristPlaces.name: Tirathgarh Falls
touristPlaces.description: Waterfall near Jagdalpur, a scenic and spiritual site.

states.name: Gujarat
states.history: Formed on May 1, 1960, Gujarat was carved out of the Bombay State along with Maharashtra. The region has a long and rich history, from the Indus Valley Civilization at Lothal, to the rule of Mauryas, Solankis, and Mughals. Gujarat is also the birthplace of Mahatma Gandhi. Post-independence, it has become a major hub for industry, trade, and entrepreneurship.

touristPlaces.name: Dwarkadhish Temple
touristPlaces.description: A major Hindu pilgrimage site dedicated to Lord Krishna.

touristPlaces.name: Somnath Temple
touristPlaces.description: One of the 12 Jyotirlinga shrines of Lord Shiva.

touristPlaces.name: Rann of Kutch
touristPlaces.description: A vast white salt desert famous for Rann Utsav.

touristPlaces.name: Statue of Unity
touristPlaces.description: World’s tallest statue, dedicated to Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.

touristPlaces.name: Gir National Park
touristPlaces.description: Only home to Asiatic Lions in the world.

states.name: Haryana
states.tagline: The Land of Milk and Ghee

facts.famousFood: Bajra Khichdi, Churma, Kachri ki Sabzi

states.history: Haryana was created on November 1, 1966, after the division of Punjab on linguistic lines. Historically, it was part of the Vedic region of Kurukshetra, the setting of the Mahabharata. In modern India, it is known for its contribution to agriculture (Green Revolution), sports, and industrial development around Gurugram and Faridabad.

touristPlaces.name: Kurukshetra
touristPlaces.description: Historical battlefield of the Mahabharata.

touristPlaces.name: Sultanpur Bird Sanctuary
touristPlaces.description: A birdwatcher's paradise with migratory species.

touristPlaces.name: Pinjore Gardens
touristPlaces.description: Beautiful Mughal-era terraced gardens near Chandigarh.

touristPlaces.name: Morni Hills
touristPlaces.description: Scenic hill station in the Shivalik ranges.

touristPlaces.name: Karna Lake
touristPlaces.description: A recreational lake linked with Karna from the Mahabharata.

states.name: Himachal Pradesh
states.history: Composed of many princely hill states, Himachal Pradesh became a Union Territory in 1950 and achieved full statehood on January 25, 1971. The region was once under the control of the Mughals, Sikhs, and British. Known for its natural beauty, tourism, and apple orchards, it is also referred to as “Dev Bhoomi” (Land of the Gods).

touristPlaces.name: Shimla
touristPlaces.description: The Queen of Hills and former British summer capital.

touristPlaces.name: Manali
touristPlaces.description: Popular hill station for honeymooners and trekkers.

touristPlaces.name: Dharamshala
touristPlaces.description: Home to the Dalai Lama and Tibetan culture.

touristPlaces.name: Kullu Valley
touristPlaces.description: Valley of Gods, famous for apple orchards and Dussehra festival.

touristPlaces.name: Spiti Valley
touristPlaces.description: Cold desert valley with monasteries and high-altitude treks.

states.name: Jharkhand
states.history: Created on November 15, 2000, from Bihar, Jharkhand has long been home to various tribal communities and played a role in several tribal uprisings against the British. Rich in minerals like coal, iron, and mica, it contributes significantly to India's industry. Ranchi, the capital, was once the summer capital of Bihar.

touristPlaces.name: Betla National Park
touristPlaces.description: Rich wildlife reserve in the Palamu district.

touristPlaces.name: Dassam Falls
touristPlaces.description: A beautiful 144 ft waterfall near Ranchi.

touristPlaces.name: Parasnath Hill
touristPlaces.description: Important Jain pilgrimage site, the highest hill in Jharkhand.

touristPlaces.name: Hundru Falls
touristPlaces.description: One of the highest waterfalls in the state.

touristPlaces.name: Netarhat
touristPlaces.description: Popularly known as the 'Queen of Chotanagpur'.

states.name: Manipur
states.history: Manipur was an independent kingdom with its own constitution and royal family until it merged with India in 1949. It became a full-fledged state on January 21, 1972. Manipur has a rich tradition of dance (Raas Leela), martial arts, and indigenous sports. It has faced long-standing insurgency and ethnic tensions but remains a culturally vibrant part of the Northeast.

touristPlaces.name: Loktak Lake
touristPlaces.description: Largest freshwater lake in Northeast India, famous for floating islands (Phumdis).

touristPlaces.name: Kangla Fort
touristPlaces.description: Historic fort and cultural heritage site in Imphal.

touristPlaces.name: Keibul Lamjao National Park
touristPlaces.description: World’s only floating national park, home to Sangai deer.

touristPlaces.name: Shree Govindajee Temple
touristPlaces.description: Historic Vaishnavite temple near Kangla Fort.

touristPlaces.name: Shirui Hills
touristPlaces.description: Home to the rare Shirui Lily flower.

states.name: Meghalaya
states.history: Carved out of Assam, Meghalaya became a full state on January 21, 1972. It was originally part of the Khasi and Jaintia Hills under British rule. Meghalaya, meaning 'Abode of Clouds,' is home to the Khasi, Garo, and Jaintia tribes, each with distinct matrilineal cultures. Known for its scenic landscapes and the world's wettest places like Mawsynram, it has been relatively peaceful compared to neighboring states.

touristPlaces.name: Cherrapunji
touristPlaces.description: One of the wettest places on Earth, famous for living root bridges.

touristPlaces.name: Mawsynram
touristPlaces.description: The wettest place on Earth.

touristPlaces.name: Shillong Peak
touristPlaces.description: Highest point in Shillong offering panoramic views.

touristPlaces.name: Dawki
touristPlaces.description: Crystal-clear Umngot River famous for boating.

touristPlaces.name: Nohkalikai Falls
touristPlaces.description: Tallest plunge waterfall in India.

states.name: Mizoram
states.history: Formerly part of Assam, Mizoram saw unrest in the 1960s after the Mizo National Front (MNF) rebelled. A peace accord in 1986 between the MNF and the Indian government led to Mizoram attaining statehood on February 20, 1987. It has strong Christian missionary influence, is among India’s most literate states, and maintains peaceful relations despite its earlier insurgency.

touristPlaces.name: Aizawl
touristPlaces.description: The capital, known for scenic viewpoints and vibrant markets.

touristPlaces.name: Reiek
touristPlaces.description: Picturesque hill and heritage village.

touristPlaces.name: Phawngpui
touristPlaces.description: Also called Blue Mountain, highest peak in Mizoram.

touristPlaces.name: Tam Dil Lake
touristPlaces.description: Beautiful lake surrounded by thick forests.

touristPlaces.name: Vantawng Falls
touristPlaces.description: The highest waterfall in Mizoram, cascading through lush forests.

states.name: Nagaland

facts.famousFood: Smoked Pork with Bamboo Shoot, Bamboo Steamed Fish

states.history: Nagaland was the first northeastern state to be carved out from Assam in 1963. The region was known for fierce Naga tribes, and in post-independence years, it witnessed separatist movements for sovereignty. A fragile ceasefire has held since the 1990s, with ongoing peace talks. Nagaland is culturally rich with festivals like Hornbill, and is largely Christian.

touristPlaces.name: Kohima War Cemetery
touristPlaces.description: Memorial for soldiers of World War II.

touristPlaces.name: Hornbill Festival
touristPlaces.description: A major cultural festival showcasing the tribal heritage of Nagaland.

touristPlaces.name: Dzükou Valley
touristPlaces.description: A breathtaking valley with seasonal flowers, perfect for trekking.

touristPlaces.name: Japfu Peak
touristPlaces.description: Second-highest peak in Nagaland, great for trekking.

touristPlaces.name: Tuophema Village
touristPlaces.description: Heritage village promoting Naga traditions.

states.name: Odisha
states.history: Odisha, formerly Orissa, has ancient links to the Kalinga kingdom, which famously turned Emperor Ashoka towards Buddhism after the bloody Kalinga War (261 BCE). It became a separate province in 1936, making it the first state created on linguistic basis for Odia speakers. Renamed Odisha in 2011, the state is known for Jagannath Puri, Konark Sun Temple, and tribal communities.

touristPlaces.name: Jagannath Temple, Puri
touristPlaces.description: Famous Hindu temple and site of the Rath Yatra.

touristPlaces.name: Konark Sun Temple
touristPlaces.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site famous for its intricate architecture and historical significance.

touristPlaces.name: Chilika Lake
touristPlaces.description: Asia's largest brackish water lagoon, home to migratory birds and dolphins.

touristPlaces.name: Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves
touristPlaces.description: Historic caves with Jain carvings.

touristPlaces.name: Simlipal National Park
touristPlaces.description: Tiger reserve and biosphere reserve.

states.name: Punjab

facts.famousFood: Makki di Roti, Sarson da Saag, Butter Chicken

states.history: Punjab has a rich ancient and medieval history, being the land of the Indus Valley Civilization, Vedic culture, and later the Sikh Gurus. It was partitioned in 1947, leading to massive migration and trauma. In 1966, it was reorganized on linguistic lines, with Haryana and Himachal Pradesh carved out. Punjab is today a Sikh-majority state, known for agriculture, bhangra music, and military contributions.

touristPlaces.name: Golden Temple
touristPlaces.description: A sacred Sikh shrine in Amritsar known for its golden structure and spiritual significance.

touristPlaces.name: Wagah Border
touristPlaces.description: Famous for the daily military ceremony between India and Pakistan.

touristPlaces.name: Jallianwala Bagh
touristPlaces.description: Historical site of the tragic 1919 massacre, now a memorial park in Amritsar.

touristPlaces.name: Anandpur Sahib
touristPlaces.description: A holy city in Rupnagar, known for its Sikh history and festivals like Hola Mohalla.

touristPlaces.name: Sheesh Mahal
touristPlaces.description: A beautiful palace in Patiala with intricate mirror work and royal architecture.

states.name: Sikkim
states.history: Sikkim was an independent Buddhist kingdom ruled by the Chogyal dynasty. In 1947, it became a protectorate of India, retaining autonomy. Following political unrest and a referendum in 1975, Sikkim voted to join India and became the 22nd state. It is India's second smallest state and is known for Mount Kanchenjunga, monasteries, and its peaceful integration into the Indian Union. It retains its distinct Tibeto-Buddhist culture.

touristPlaces.name: Tsomgo Lake
touristPlaces.description: A high-altitude lake known for its stunning reflection and changing colors.

touristPlaces.name: Rumtek Monastery
touristPlaces.description: One of the largest Buddhist monasteries in Sikkim.

touristPlaces.name: Nathula Pass
touristPlaces.description: Mountain pass connecting India and Tibet.

touristPlaces.name: Yumthang Valley
touristPlaces.description: Known as the Valley of Flowers of Sikkim.

touristPlaces.name: Pelling
touristPlaces.description: Famous for views of Kanchenjunga peak.

states.name: Telangana
states.history: Telangana was part of the Hyderabad State under the Nizam before merging with India in 1948. It was joined with Andhra State in 1956 to form Andhra Pradesh. However, due to perceived neglect, a long movement for separate statehood was led by various student and political groups. After decades of protests, Telangana was officially formed on June 2, 2014, as India’s 29th state (later 28th after J&K split). Hyderabad is its capital and also serves Andhra for 10 years as part of the bifurcation agreement.

touristPlaces.name: Charminar
touristPlaces.description: Iconic monument in Hyderabad, built in 1591.

touristPlaces.name: Golconda Fort
touristPlaces.description: A grand fortress known for its architecture and acoustics.

touristPlaces.name: Ramoji Film City
touristPlaces.description: World’s largest film studio complex, tourist hotspot.

touristPlaces.name: Hussain Sagar Lake
touristPlaces.description: Artificial lake with giant Buddha statue in the center.

touristPlaces.name: Thousand Pillar Temple
touristPlaces.description: Historic temple at Warangal with Kakatiya architecture.

states.name: Tripura
states.history: Tripura was one of the princely states that acceded to India in 1949. It became a Union Territory and achieved full statehood on January 21, 1972. The region has a mix of tribal and Bengali cultures, and saw insurgency issues post-Partition due to large-scale migration. It is now largely peaceful, with significant contributions in handicrafts, bamboo art, and political awareness.

touristPlaces.name: Neermahal
touristPlaces.description: A water palace in the middle of Rudrasagar Lake, blending Hindu and Mughal architecture.

touristPlaces.name: Unakoti
touristPlaces.description: Rock-cut sculptures and carvings dating back to 7th–9th century.

touristPlaces.name: Ujjayanta Palace
touristPlaces.description: Royal palace in Agartala, now a museum.

touristPlaces.name: Jampui Hills
touristPlaces.description: Famous for orange orchards and scenic views.

touristPlaces.name: Sepahijala Wildlife Sanctuary
touristPlaces.description: Known for clouded leopards and primates.

states.name: Uttarakhand

facts.famousFood: Aloo Ke Gutke, Kafuli, Bal Mithai

states.history: Formed on November 9, 2000, from the hill districts of Uttar Pradesh, it was initially named Uttaranchal, later changed to Uttarakhand in 2007. Known as the 'Dev Bhoomi' (Land of the Gods), it is home to sacred Hindu sites like Kedarnath, Badrinath, Haridwar, and Gangotri. It has a rich tradition of folk culture and Pahari heritage. Natural disasters like the 2013 floods deeply impacted the state, yet it continues to grow in eco-tourism and hydropower.

touristPlaces.name: Kedarnath Temple
touristPlaces.description: One of the twelve Jyotirlingas dedicated to Lord Shiva.

touristPlaces.name: Badrinath Temple
touristPlaces.description: One of the Char Dham pilgrimage sites.

touristPlaces.name: Valley of Flowers
touristPlaces.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site famous for endemic flora and alpine meadows.

touristPlaces.name: Haridwar
touristPlaces.description: A sacred city on the banks of the Ganges known for Ganga Aarti.

touristPlaces.name: Nainital
touristPlaces.description: Scenic hill station known for Naini Lake.

states.name: Goa

facts.famousFood: Fish Curry Rice, Pork Vindaloo, Bebinca, Feni

states.history: Goa, located on the western coast of India, has a rich and unique history influenced by centuries of foreign rule. Originally part of the Mauryan Empire in the 3rd century BCE, Goa later came under the rule of the Kadambas, Chalukyas, and Yadavas. In 1510, the Portuguese, led by Afonso de Albuquerque, captured Goa from the Sultan of Bijapur and established it as the capital of Portuguese India. For over 450 years, Goa remained a Portuguese colony, making it the longest-held European colony in India. This colonial legacy deeply influenced Goa's architecture, religion (predominantly Catholicism), language, and culture. After India's independence in 1947, Portugal refused to hand over Goa. In response, India launched Operation Vijay on December 18, 1961, and liberated Goa, along with Daman and Diu, on December 19, 1961. Initially made a Union Territory, Goa was later granted statehood on May 30, 1987, becoming India’s 25th state. Today, Goa is known for its beautiful beaches, world heritage churches, vibrant festivals, and a unique blend of Indian and Portuguese cultures.

touristPlaces.name: Baga Beach
touristPlaces.description: One of the most famous beaches in Goa, known for nightlife and water sports.

touristPlaces.name: Calangute Beach
touristPlaces.description: Queen of Beaches with water sports and vibrant nightlife.

touristPlaces.name: Basilica of Bom Jesus
touristPlaces.description: UNESCO site housing St. Francis Xavier's relics.

touristPlaces.name: Dudhsagar Falls
touristPlaces.description: Four-tiered waterfall resembling a sea of milk.

touristPlaces.name: Fort Aguada
touristPlaces.description: A 17th-century Portuguese fort overlooking the Arabian Sea.

states.name: West Bengal

facts.famousFood: Macher Jhol, Shorshe Ilish, Rasgulla, Sandesh

states.history: Once the center of British India, Bengal was partitioned during independence in 1947, leading to the formation of East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) and West Bengal as part of India. Historically, it was the home of Bengal Renaissance, and the base for reformers and revolutionaries like Raja Ram Mohan Roy, Subhas Chandra Bose, and Rabindranath Tagore. West Bengal was earlier united with Odisha and Bihar but became a separate state post-independence. Kolkata, its capital, remains a hub of literature, art, and politics.

touristPlaces.name: Victoria Memorial
touristPlaces.description: A grand white marble museum built in memory of Queen Victoria.

touristPlaces.name: Sundarbans
touristPlaces.description: World’s largest mangrove forest and habitat of the Royal Bengal Tiger.

touristPlaces.name: Darjeeling
touristPlaces.description: Hill station famous for tea, toy train, and Kanchenjunga views.

touristPlaces.name: Dakshineswar Kali Temple
touristPlaces.description: Renowned Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Kali, near Kolkata.

touristPlaces.name: Howrah Bridge
touristPlaces.description: Cantilever bridge over the Hooghly River, symbol of Kolkata.
